item.title: Demon Slayer: The Hinokami Chronicles 2 Confirmed for 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/demon-slayer-the-hinokami-chronicles-2-confirmed-for-2025/

Demon Slayer: The Hinokami Chronicles 2 will be released for PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X/S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, and PC via Steam in 2025. 

Sega has released an announcement trailer for Demon Slayer: The Hinokami Chronicles 2, revealing new details about the upcoming title. Firstly, players get to see glimpses of all 9 Hashiras and their special moves: Giyu Tomioka, Kyōjurō Rengoku, Tengen Uzui, Shinobu Kocho, Muichiro Tokito, Mitsuri Kanroji, Obanai Iguro, Sanemi Shinazugawa and Gyomei Himejima. All 9 Hashiras will be playable in the upcoming title. 

The Demon Slayer: The Hinokami Chronicles 2 announcement trailer also gives fans a glimpse of the sequel’s story, featuring three new arcs. The upcoming game will let players experience the events of the Entertainment District Arc, The Swordsmith Village Arc, and The Hashira Training Arc. Lastly, the sequel’s roster will feature 40 playable characters, including all the base game and DLC characters from the original title. 

In other news, Hunter x Hunter Nen X Impact has been banned in Australia. Also, Marvel Rivals leaks have revealed new details about The Thing and Ultron. Will you play Demon Slayer: The Hinokami Chronicles 2 once it arrives in 2025? Let us know in the comments or our new community forum!

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Marvel Rivals leaks revealing details about The Thing and Ultron. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.  

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: Hunter X Hunter Nen X Impact Banned in Australia
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/hunter-x-hunter-nen-x-impact-refused-classification-in-australia/

The Australian Classification Board has refused to classify Hunter X Hunter Nen X Impact.

If you head to the Australian Classification Board website, you will see that Hunter x Hunter Nen x Impact has been classified as ‘RC’ or ‘Refused Classification’. The website has not provided a reason for refusing classification and has asked fans to contact them for further clarification on their decision. 

The Australian Classification Board provided a statement to Polygon regarding the classification of Hunter x Hunter Nen X Impact, explaining that the game was refused classification due to “a visual depiction of implied sexual violence, where an adult male exposes himself to persons under the age of 18 years.” 

The Australian Classification Board added: 

“The Board noted in its report that the implied sexual violence is implicitly condoned as appropriate due to a lack of resolution of the act through the game’s narrative and that it is not justified by context. Implied sexual violence that is visually depicted, interactive, not justified by context, or related to incentives or rewards is not permitted.” 

Currently, Hunter X Hunter Nen X Impact does not have a concrete release date, but it is scheduled to arrive at some point in 2025 for PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch, and PC. 

In other news, Palworld has changed how Pal Spheres work in the game. Also, Apple and Sony are reportedly partnering up to create Vision Pro controllers. What are your thoughts on Hunter X Hunter Nen x Impact being banned in Australia? Let us know in the comments or our new community forum!

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Marvel Rivals leaks revealing details about The Thing and Ultron. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Marvel Rivals Leaks Reveal Details About Ultron and The Thing
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/marvel-rivals-leaks-reveals-details-about-ultron-and-the-thing/

Leaks about upcoming playable Marvel Rivals characters have surfaced online, revealing new details about Ultron and The Thing. 

Marvel Rivals The Thing Leak

The Thing is set to be another Tank for Marvel Rivals. The character’s passive ability is Solid as a Rock, which makes him immune to enemy knockback and displacement effects. The character’s primary attack is Combination Punch, which releases quick and continuous punches. Their secondary attack is Thunderbolt Punch, which releases a devastating blow at the enemy. 

The Thing’s E ability in Marvel Rivals is Battlefield Support, which will make him jump towards teammates and reduce damage for allies and himself. His L Shift move is Furious Charge, which triggers a Continuous Forward charge that pummels enemies in your way and leaves a seismic zone behind you. Lastly, The Thing’s ultimate is called Slam Moment, and it knocks all enemies in front of you in the air. 

Marvel Rivals Ultron Leak 

As per RivalLeaks on X (formerly Twitter), Ultron will be a supporting character in Marvel Rivals. His primary attack will be the Encephalo-Ray, an energy beam, and his secondary move is Dynamic Flight, which allows him to quickly fly in the direction of movement and then enter a free-flight mode. Ultron’s E ability is Imperative: Firewall, which provides health to allies within range with the help of drones. 

Ultron’s L Shift ability in Marvel Rivals is Imperative: Patch, which releases a giant drone that follows an ally, healing them and others within range. Ultron’s passive ability, called Algorithm Correction, allows him to jump and fall slowly. His ultimate is Rage of Ultron, which releases Ultron Drones that Encephalo-Rays at enemies or heal allies. RivalLeaks added in another post that Ultron might be released sooner than we think. 

Players should know that Marvel Rivals has not officially announced The Thing or Ultron as upcoming playable characters.

In other news, Marvel Rivals has hit 10 million players in just three days. Also, here’s how to get the Iron Man Armor Model 42 Costume in the game. What are your thoughts on The Thing and Ultron’s coming Marvel Rivals? Let us know in the comments or our new community forum!

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Apple and Sony partnering up for Vision Pro controllers. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.
